An Achievable Rate Region for Interference Channels
with Conferencing

Yi Cao and Biao Chen Department of EECS, Syracuse University, Syracuse, NY 13244
Email: ycao01@syr.edu, bichen@ecs.syr.edu
Abstract

In this paper, we propose an achievable rate region for discrete memoryless interference channels with conferencing at the transmitter side. We employ superposition block Markov encoding, combined with simultaneous superposition coding, dirty paper coding, and random binning to obtain the achievable rate region. We show that, under respective conditions, the proposed achievable region reduces to Han and Kobayashiâ€™s achievable region for interference channels, the capacity region for degraded relay channels, and the capacity region for the Gaussian vector broadcast channel. Numerical examples for the Gaussian case are given.

Index terms â€” interference channels, dirty paper coding, superposition block Markov encoding, random binning.

I Introduction

The capacity region of an interference channel (IC), where the information sources at the two transmitters are statistically independent, has been a long standing problem. Carleial was the first to use the superposition code idea [1] to obtain an inner bound for IC. This inner bound was later improved by Han and Kobayashi [2] who gave an achievable rate region that is the largest reported to this date. Recently, a simplified description of the Han-Kobayashi (HK) rate region for the general IC is derived by Chong-Motani-Garg in [3].

A related and less well investigated problem is when the information sources at the two transmitters are correlated, i.e., interference channel with common information (ICCI) [4, 5]. In [4], an achievable rate region, an outer bound, and a limiting expression for the capacity region were obtained. Later, the capacity region of this channel under strong interference was found in [5]. Recently, improved achievable regions for general ICCI [6, 7] and three new outer bounds for the capacity region of Gaussian ICCI [8] were proposed. However, all those results are based on the assumption that the common message is available noncausally.

In this work, we investigate the problem of user cooperation in interference channels for the causal case. Here, each user not only transmits his own message to the intended receiver, but also serves as a relay to help transmit part of the other userâ€™s message. We apply the superposition block Markov encoding, which was used previously for the relay channel [9] and for user cooperation in multiple access channels [10]. Our proposed achievable rate region is a generalized form of the HK region for IC [2], the capacity region of degraded relay channels [9], and the capacity region of the Gaussian vector broadcast channel (GVBC) [11].

This paper is organized as follows. In section II, we present the channel model and review some existing results. In section III, we propose an achievable region for general IC with transmitter conferencing. In section IV, numerical examples are used to compare the proposed region with the HK region and the capacity region of GVBC. We conclude in section V.

III Main Results

We first give a brief outline of our encoding-decoding strategy. We split each userâ€™s message into two parts: Mğ‘€M and Wğ‘ŠW, where Mğ‘€M is to be sent directly to the intended receiver, and Wğ‘ŠW is the cooperative message to be sent to the receiver via the cooperation of the other user (relay). Our cooperation strategy is based on superposition block Markov encoding with the assumption that Wğ‘ŠW can be perfectly decoded by the relay. The purpose of introducing Mğ‘€M is to achieve a reasonable rate region (no less than IC without conferencing) even when the conferencing channel is poor. For the message Mğ‘€M, we apply simultaneous superposition coding [2] and further split it into two parts: private message Vğ‘‰V and common message Uğ‘ˆU.

For the cooperation in transmitting Wğ‘ŠW, we jointly consider BğµB blocks, each of nğ‘›n symbols. Each user transmits a sequence of Bâˆ’1ğµ1B-1 messages w1,â‹¯,wBâˆ’1subscriptğ‘¤1â‹¯subscriptğ‘¤ğµ1w_{1},\cdot\cdot\cdot,w_{B-1} in BğµB blocks, with no new message in the last block. Note that as Bâ†’âˆâ†’ğµB\rightarrow\infty, (Bâˆ’1)/Bğµ1ğµ(B-1)/B is arbitrarily close to 111, hence the penalty on rate is negligible. Now we take user 1 as an example to show the whole process. Suppose there are 2nâ€‹R13superscript2ğ‘›subscriptğ‘…132^{nR_{13}} codewords of W1subscriptğ‘Š1W_{1} for user 1 to transmit. We establish a random partition by randomly throwing them into 2nâ€‹R10superscript2ğ‘›subscriptğ‘…102^{nR_{10}} cells. This partition is made known to both transmitters and receivers. Suppose user 1 sends message w1,bâˆ’1subscriptğ‘¤1ğ‘1w_{1,b-1} at block bâˆ’1ğ‘1b-1. At the end of block bâˆ’1ğ‘1b-1, following our assumption, user 2 can perfectly decode w1,bâˆ’1subscriptğ‘¤1ğ‘1w_{1,b-1} and calculate the cell index s1â€‹bsubscriptğ‘ 1ğ‘s_{1b} to which w1,bâˆ’1subscriptğ‘¤1ğ‘1w_{1,b-1} belongs. At block bğ‘b, both user 1 and 2 spend some power transmitting s1â€‹bsubscriptğ‘ 1ğ‘s_{1b}. This provides the basis for cooperatively resolving the remaining Y1subscriptğ‘Œ1Y_{1} uncertainty about w1,bâˆ’1subscriptğ‘¤1ğ‘1w_{1,b-1}. After decoding s1â€‹bsubscriptğ‘ 1ğ‘s_{1b} at the end of block bğ‘b, receiver Y1subscriptğ‘Œ1Y_{1} intersects its ambiguity set ğ’Ÿâ€‹(y1â€‹(bâˆ’1))ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ‘¦1ğ‘1\mathcal{D}(y_{1}(b-1)) (i.e., the set of all codewords wğ‘¤w that are jointly typical with y1,bâˆ’1subscriptğ‘¦1ğ‘1y_{1,b-1}[9]) with cell s1â€‹bsubscriptğ‘ 1ğ‘s_{1b} and gets the unique correct codeword w1,bâˆ’1subscriptğ‘¤1ğ‘1w_{1,b-1} with a probability close to 1.

Since both users 1 and 2 can perfectly decode each otherâ€™s messages W1subscriptğ‘Š1W_{1}, W2subscriptğ‘Š2W_{2} and then calculate the corresponding cell indices S1,S2subscriptğ‘†1subscriptğ‘†2S_{1},S_{2}, we can employ dirty paper coding (DPC) to transmit V1,U1subscriptğ‘‰1subscriptğ‘ˆ1V_{1},U_{1} and S1subscriptğ‘†1S_{1} treating S2subscriptğ‘†2S_{2} as a known interference at transmitter 1. Similarly at transmitter 2, we can transmit V2,U2subscriptğ‘‰2subscriptğ‘ˆ2V_{2},U_{2} and S2subscriptğ‘†2S_{2} treating S1subscriptğ‘†1S_{1} as a known interference. Then, the information state of receiver Y1subscriptğ‘Œ1Y_{1} propagates forward, yielding the total decoding error probability Pe,1(n)â†’0â†’superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘’1ğ‘›0P_{e,1}^{(n)}\rightarrow 0 as nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘›n\rightarrow\infty. The analysis of Pe,2(n)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘’2ğ‘›P_{e,2}^{(n)} is similar to Pe,1(n)superscriptsubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘’1ğ‘›P_{e,1}^{(n)}, which leads to bounds (23)-(32). Thus, â„›1âˆ—superscriptsubscriptâ„›1\mathcal{R}_{1}^{*} is achievable. Proof of â„›2âˆ—superscriptsubscriptâ„›2\mathcal{R}_{2}^{*} is identical, hence â„›âˆ—superscriptâ„›\mathcal{R}^{*} is achievable for ICC via time sharing.

The cardinality bound on Qğ‘„Q, i.e., |Q|â‰¤33ğ‘„33|Q|\leq 33 is obtained by applying the Caratheodory Theorem to a set of inequalities that bound the rate pair (R1,R2)subscriptğ‘…1subscriptğ‘…2(R_{1},R_{2}), obtained via Fourier-Motzkin elimination to Eqs. (9)-(32). Q.E.D.

Remarks: From the encoding-decoding strategy of the above theorem, the achievable region â„›âˆ—superscriptâ„›\mathcal{R}^{*} is actually a generalization of the HK region for IC, the capacity region of degraded relay channels, and the capacity region of GVBC. It reduces to those extreme cases under the conditions elaborated below.

1)When the conferencing channel between the two users is very poor, the bound in (22) and (32) can be very small. In this case, allocating power for cooperation will actually reduce the rates otherwise achievable via direct transmission. As a result, the encoders will not allocate any power to transmit W1subscriptğ‘Š1W_{1} and W2subscriptğ‘Š2W_{2}, so W1=W2=S1=S2=0subscriptğ‘Š1subscriptğ‘Š2subscriptğ‘†1subscriptğ‘†20W_{1}=W_{2}=S_{1}=S_{2}=0 and G1=G2=H1=H2=0subscriptğº1subscriptğº2subscriptğ»1subscriptğ»20G_{1}=G_{2}=H_{1}=H_{2}=0. Then, both â„›1âˆ—superscriptsubscriptâ„›1\mathcal{R}_{1}^{*} and â„›2âˆ—superscriptsubscriptâ„›2\mathcal{R}_{2}^{*} reduce to the region in Proposition 1, which equals to the HK region.

2)When the conferencing channel between the two users is good enough, it is not necessary to transmit messages directly to the receiver, because cooperative transmission with the other user will always yield a better rate. In this case, the encoders will let V1=V2=U1=U2=0subscriptğ‘‰1subscriptğ‘‰2subscriptğ‘ˆ1subscriptğ‘ˆ20V_{1}=V_{2}=U_{1}=U_{2}=0 and M1=M2=N1=N2=0subscriptğ‘€1subscriptğ‘€2subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘20M_{1}=M_{2}=N_{1}=N_{2}=0. Now, if user 2 refrains from transmitting its own message and only serves as a relay to user 1 (i.e., W2=S2=G2=H2=0subscriptğ‘Š2subscriptğ‘†2subscriptğº2subscriptğ»20W_{2}=S_{2}=G_{2}=H_{2}=0), both â„›1âˆ—superscriptsubscriptâ„›1\mathcal{R}_{1}^{*} and â„›2âˆ—superscriptsubscriptâ„›2\mathcal{R}_{2}^{*} reduce to the capacity region of the degraded relay channel in Proposition 2. Similarly, if user 1 serves only as a relay to user 2, it also reduces to the capacity region of the degraded relay channel.

3)When the conferencing channel between the two users is ideal (i.e., the conferencing channel capacity is infinite), the bounds in (22) and (32) are no longer needed. So, W1=W2=G1=G2â‰ˆ0subscriptğ‘Š1subscriptğ‘Š2subscriptğº1subscriptğº20W_{1}=W_{2}=G_{1}=G_{2}\approx 0. Combining the result in case 2 that V1=V2=U1=U2=0subscriptğ‘‰1subscriptğ‘‰2subscriptğ‘ˆ1subscriptğ‘ˆ20V_{1}=V_{2}=U_{1}=U_{2}=0 and M1=M2=N1=N2=0subscriptğ‘€1subscriptğ‘€2subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘20M_{1}=M_{2}=N_{1}=N_{2}=0, we can easily check that â„›1âˆ—superscriptsubscriptâ„›1\mathcal{R}_{1}^{*} reduces to

R1subscriptğ‘…1\displaystyle R_{1} â‰¤\displaystyle\leq Iâ€‹(Y1;H1|Q)âˆ’Iâ€‹(H1;S2|Q)ğ¼subscriptğ‘Œ1conditionalsubscriptğ»1ğ‘„ğ¼subscriptğ»1conditionalsubscriptğ‘†2ğ‘„\displaystyle I(Y_{1};H_{1}|Q)-I(H_{1};S_{2}|Q) (51)
R2subscriptğ‘…2\displaystyle R_{2} â‰¤\displaystyle\leq Iâ€‹(Y2;S2|Q)ğ¼subscriptğ‘Œ2conditionalsubscriptğ‘†2ğ‘„\displaystyle I(Y_{2};S_{2}|Q) (52)

and â„›2âˆ—superscriptsubscriptâ„›2\mathcal{R}_{2}^{*} reduces to

R1subscriptğ‘…1\displaystyle R_{1} â‰¤\displaystyle\leq Iâ€‹(Y1;S1|Q)ğ¼subscriptğ‘Œ1conditionalsubscriptğ‘†1ğ‘„\displaystyle I(Y_{1};S_{1}|Q) (53)
R2subscriptğ‘…2\displaystyle R_{2} â‰¤\displaystyle\leq Iâ€‹(Y2;H2|Q)âˆ’Iâ€‹(H2;S1|Q)ğ¼subscriptğ‘Œ2conditionalsubscriptğ»2ğ‘„ğ¼subscriptğ»2conditionalsubscriptğ‘†1ğ‘„\displaystyle I(Y_{2};H_{2}|Q)-I(H_{2};S_{1}|Q) (54)

For the Gaussian case, the rate region (51)-(52) becomes (6) and (53)-(54) becomes (7). So, in this case, â„›âˆ—superscriptâ„›\mathcal{R}^{*} reduces to the capacity region of GVBC.

4)During the review process of this paper, we became aware of [12], which essentially tackles the same problem using a different approach. In [12], user cooperation results in a common information (in the sense of [4]) at the encoders and the decoder uses backward decoding (similar to that of [10]) instead of the random partitioning (i.e., binning) we use in our approach. Except for some extreme cases, it appears no subset relation can be established. The obtained achievable region in [12] is simpler as it does not involve a large number of auxiliary variables; however, the scheme in [12] is strictly suboptimal for certain extreme cases (e.g., degraded relay channels, IC with degraded message sets with weak interference, and MIMO BC) whereas our achievable region can be easily shown to be optimal in each of these cases.

IV Numerical Examples

The standard form of a Gaussian interference channel is:

Remarks:

1) When there is no conferencing between the two users, the achievable region reduces to the HK region. When the quality of the conferencing channel improves, it increases our achievable region for ICC within the limit of the capacity of GVBC.

2) When the channel coefficient is K1=K2=4subscriptğ¾1subscriptğ¾24K_{1}=K_{2}=4, the region â„›â„›\mathcal{R} is already very close to the upper bound; when K1=K2=1subscriptğ¾1subscriptğ¾21K_{1}=K_{2}=1, which is equal to the channel coefficient of the transmitter to the receiver, cooperation achieves a slightly better rate region than independent transmission.

3) For the channel coefficient K1=K2=4subscriptğ¾1subscriptğ¾24K_{1}=K_{2}=4, the corresponding relay channels (i.e., one of the users only serves as a relay) are degraded, thus the intercepts of the bound at both axes are the capacities of respective relay channels.
